posts.post_content:
One of my all time favorite cards [Serra Angel](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Serra Angel) just become irrelevant. Seriously, this at 3WW is absurd. I'm not going to say they killed Magic 2010 by printing this, but they sure crippled it.. In limited this dominates battlefield and in constructed it's still awesome. In legacy it rocks and in vintage it's just ok. At least they didn't add protection from black and red. 5/5 normally, but 4/5 from a vintage player's standpoint.
  
Casual play is just as frustrating for some if they keep printing stuff like this.
posts.html:

Posted By: revilolee (11/4/2009 5:27:27 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content: As a huge fan of white Angel cards, of course I am thrilled to have this one in a deck! But, I must admit that the first time I saw it, I thought, "Shouldn't there be at least one more W in its cost?" It just seems so blatantly unbalanced. It really should have been 3WWW or 4WWW. Either way, with all of those white-type abilities, it should have had at least WWW in its cost. The "protection from Demons and from Dragons" part doesn't bother me too much. There are plenty of decks out there that won't be affected by these abilities at all. It's the fact that she's a 5/5 with flying, first strike, and lifelink. With these abilities alone, she should cost at least one more White.
posts.html:

Posted By: VirtueVsVice (2/2/2010 11:37:11 AM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
It's a powerful creature card with an efficient casting cost. Because of that, the card is insanely priced, especially since it was in a deck that won a Pro Tour qualifier. Even though there are plenty of low-cost creature removal cards in all formats, Baneslayer Angel demands attention when it enters the battlefield. It is a threat that cannot be ignored.  
  
[Juzám Djinn](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Juzám Djinn) is also a creature card that has a high retail price, because it is powerful and efficient for its casting cost. Thus, even after Baneslayer Angel rotates out of Standard, I expect its retail price to remain relatively high.
posts.html:
It's a powerful creature card with an efficient casting cost. Because of that, the card is insanely priced, especially since it was in a deck that won a Pro Tour qualifier. Even though there are plenty of low-cost creature removal cards in all formats, Baneslayer Angel demands attention when it enters the battlefield. It is a threat that cannot be ignored.

Juzám Djinn is also a creature card that has a high retail price, because it is powerful and efficient for its casting cost. Thus, even after Baneslayer Angel rotates out of Standard, I expect its retail price to remain relatively high.

Posted By: ClowWizardEriol (2/6/2010 4:36:29 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
At 3WW she is insanely cheap, but hardly a "GIN" card when she arrives. I always stack my decks with plenty of creature control and my crosshairs would drop on her as soon as she hit the table. Cards like this are mythically rare for a reason. It would take someone a fortune to get four of her in their deck and if they have the Money to do that, then their deck is probably ridiculous in the first place.
  
   
I LIKE the fact that Hasbro creates cards like this and makes them hard to find. It adds a mystery and luck to the game. Powerful cards should be extremely rare. The game is more strategy than "who can put the most powerful creatures in their decks." I've built very successful decks out of commons and uncommons with nothing with a mana cost above 3 and kicked some serious \*\*\* with them.
  
   
Any card can be dealt with: doom blade, deathmark, terror, pacify, divine verdict, seismic strike, fireball, blinding mage, assassinate etc. need I say more?
posts.html:

Posted By: xonix2002 (3/11/2010 9:21:27 AM)

posts.post_content:
No offense, but anyone not giving this thing a 5/5 does not realize how absurdly broken this card is.  
  
"Oooooh it dies to removal, this card suxors."  
  
Yeah, and so does 95% of the creatures out there. Unlike most of those creatures though, an unanswered Baneslayer basically says: You win.  
  
And no, I'm not one of the guys who goes out and buys a playset of the "staple" cards to keep fresh decks..the most I've spent on a single card is like $2, and then I trade for card I think would be effective. Yet cards like this make me cringe at how over-powered they are.
